Technology
38
The Learning Lens: VI
Except for the human brain itself,
television is the most structurally
complex instrument of education.
etv’s impact on education has been
and will be decidedly influenced by
its technology. The major techni¬
cal facts of life in etv are:
Circuitry—etv is transmitted
either by closed- or open-circuit
systems. Closed-circuit television
usually operates over cables, like
the telephone. Since it does not send
picture and sound through the air,
closed-circuit television requires
no allocation of television channels
and is outside the jurisdiction of
the F. C.C. It reaches only so far as
its cables reach. The most exten¬
sive system of closed-circuit teach¬
ing by television is at Hagerstown,
Maryland, where most of the
schools in an entire county are
linked by cable. The principal
drawbacks to closed-circuit sys-
Hagerstown, Maryland, points proudly to its his¬
tory as a famous wagon stop on the National
Road, now U. S. 40; as home of Gruber’s Hag¬
erstown Almanac, three years older than the
Farmer’s Almanac; as first to fluoridate its water
system; and as the site of fine schools and a pipe-
organ factory. Since September, 1956, perhaps its
most widely known civic attraction has been ETV.
Hagerstown is the center of the Washington
County Closed-Circuit Educational Television
Project. The most intensively developed in-sehool
television system in the United States, it draws
about 2,500 visitors a year from every state and
continent — teachers, school administrators, jour¬
nalists, technicians, and the plain curious. A full¬
time official had to be hired to handle visitors and
requests for information. ETV workshops are
conducted for teachers from other school systems.
Hagerstown school personnel are in demand to
speak throughout the country, and School Super¬
intendent William M. Brish visited India as a
consultant on introducing televised instruction
in secondary education.
As a showplace for ETV, Hagerstown is both
typical and atypical. No school system’s ETV
program has been so heavily subsidized. The
Ford Foundation and the Fund for the Advance¬
ment of Education have made grants totaling
$1,173,910. Television and telephone companies
have contributed more than $300,000 worth of
equipment. New ETV teaching devices, like those
